Mr.. EDITOR,


1t is an unpleasant task to take any notice Of a
being who is so far sunk as to be proud of his own
shame, and one who glories in being known as the
author of pitful and disgracefu falsehoods. have
been led to these remarks by the notice OF several
pieces published in paper in your piace--which
once had some claim to decency !; but by admitting
the production Of all coors into its columns, has des
cended to situation that may be pitied but cannot
be envied. will now take some notice of piece
published in the Delaware Gazette of the 10Th,
signed g. A LOCKER on This, by the by, is
ry appropriate signature for man who has the lib
erty to look on the best Houses 10 his Neghborhood
but as 10 the inside ofthe House where he is pleas
ed to say he witnessed such scenes, he knows NO
such thing for his credit is not sufficient to gain
him an admttance into its door. do not lind fault
with his notice of the gentlemen who attended this
meeting. They care nothing for his falsehoods
knowing we'll the contempt in which his character
is held but the abuse ofGovernor Kent is the sun
kindest cut of all-lt is but very short time since
the Governor exercised his constitutional preroga
tive to save this same LOCKER on from the punish
ment due to his crimes (; and it may not be amiss TO
state the manner of deceiving the Governor out of
this pardon. 1t was done by stating that Mr.. Hark
ers famous correspondent engaged in procuring
subjects for dissection for the Young Students of
Medicine in Elkton, on the night which he was
charged with committing certain crimes. hearth
ly wish Mr.. Harker all the advantage of this Resur
rectionists talents, and inform (.My. LOCKER on)
that when he favors the public with another decent
account of the People Of Elkton will give more
minute account of him. CASTIGATOR.

ing in their preamble thus express themselves


The citizens now assembled have seen with as
tonshment and regret, and not without alarm, the
course pursued by many of the opponents of the
present Administration OF the General Government
they have witnessed an unremitted and bitter hos
tility manifested to Administration pursuing mea-
sures which have received the sanction Of preced-
ing administrations, and the appreciation of the peo-
pie themselves-and they have seen urged, with AN
unwearied pertinacty, objections which, in their
opinion, are aimed at instead OF measures They
have seen public servants prescribed, whose whole
lives and talents have been devoted to the common
welfare and glory of our country, upon suspicion.
unsustaned by facts-and they have witnessed these
suspicious urged an every possible form for nearl


three gears, 1oathout the exhibition Of single proc
zuhich reason admit Under these circumstances
they deem it their duty TO sustain, by their inAu
ence and example, however humble, an Administra
ton which they conscienousy believe to have a
heart the best interests ofthe country, and to be full
ly deserving the mead Of appreciation.

writer in the United States Gazette, declares

GlBRALTEK.-Ihe he advlces from GIbrater, are
to the 18th ult. The Chronicle of the 14th states
that the Insurgents Spain, to the number Of about
1000, took possession Of Reus, lin Catalonia) on the
9Th of September, and imprisoned the principal n-
habitants until they paid certain contributions. The
rebels had previously entered Vendrel, where they
levied $4,000 and were masters Of Blanes and 9TH
er places on the coast 400 troops had arrived at
Tarragona from Valencia, and subsequently march
ed out, The Madrid Gazette of the 4h, which had
previously kept strict silence on the matters, gives
detailed account of the proceedings of the rebels
since 1925, and concludes with royal order, di-
rectng considerable body Of troops of the line to
be sent to Catalonia, and announcing that general
officer will be appointed to superintend the military
operations, with powers from his Majesty to pardon
the rebels, excepting the leaders.


DR.. Muse has made this season, on fve acres Of
land, notwithstanding severe drought ninety bar
Teis OF shell-corn, wanting peck and half-that is
ninety bushels per acre, wanting small fraction of
bushel. On ten acres he made also, this
hundred and fytOo barrels shelLeorn, or 760 bush
els-that is 70 bushels per acre


Eastern Shore Chronicle.


EMYGRATIoNs FROM THE CONTINENT OF EURopf.
A French paper which has been lying before us for
some time, mentions facts relating to the emi-
grations from Switzerland and Alsace, which we are
desirous Of publishing.


Havre has been for several years the point of en-
barkation for great numbers Of poor families from
Asace and Switzerland, for the U. States and the
details of their prudence and econumy before leav-
ing Europe, would be as remarkable as their indus.
try and success usually are after their arrival on this
side of the Atlantic. They performed journey Of
two hundred leagues through the centre OF France,
at less expence than conlon traveller would spend
in going from Havre tn Paris. The father of fam
lily provides horse and wagon. made OF pieces Of
the fir of Monnt Jura- In this he puts little straw
few kitchen utensils Of coarse pottery, and lit
tie bag of Indian meal and this forms the amount
Of their preparations for the journey. They drink
water and their thirst is satisfied and they
ter an inn ON their route, be small Or hum
Bile. When they reach the shore they sell the
horse, but the Wagon is taken in pieces and put
board the ship.


These plain and simple people are described as
large and robust, with frames unmpared by the lux
ures of civilization On reaching the United States,
they commence their journey irYmediately for the
interior. Those who first came out, said to have
encountered great trials and discouragements but
they have since become large proprietors, SO that
those who now arrive, welcomed by friends and
Immediately to the comforts Of life.


The editor Of the paper before US remarks, that
Judging from the numbers who lave emigrated with
in two or three years, whole districts will eventually
be peoped by men Of that race 5, and the names Of
Alsace, French Ecompte, &c. will be transferred to
America. N. Y. Dailyl

From the 7soy. N. r SentineLl
The following article from the Buffalo Journal o
the 9th inst. viii be read with attention. The Jour
nal has ever been decided supporter OF Mr.. Gin
ton, in state politics, aud the maniness and lndepen
dence of its sentiments as expressed below, arr
therefore the more striking and honourable.


lNr. Giaaton-It has been asserted in several o
the papers. that Mr. Clinton had finally formed ar
alliance offensive 4 defensive, with Mr. Van Buren,
and that of the articles Of the treaty was. tina
Clinton should support Gen. Jackson TOR the Presl
Gency, and himself be the candidate for Vice Pres
ident. The bodness s. air Of certainty with whicl
the assertion was made at first impressed us with
partial belief Of its truth but, after much observa
ton, the unwelcome nature of the news; or th
dulness of our perception, has prevented our com


ing fully to the understanding that such is the fact
in its full sense The American first prOclaims thu
news-the Argus does not deny it; and the Rich
mond Enquirer says he knew it six weeks ago Or
the back of this the Evening Post says: '.We arr
indeed aware that the scurril0us columns of an Ad
ans paper proclaimed in broad terms the slander
that coalition had been entered into between Mr..
Clinton and Mr.. Van Buren,. by which the latter
had agreed to support the former for the office o
Vice President, but the falsehood unfortunate
one, and not beieved.''


So that look where we will (Mr. Clinton not vet
having committed himselfby any public act) we are
at loss how to determine the point. One thing
is certan-let Mr.. Clinton 60 where he may, his
former friends will be found the firm and efficient
supporters of the present Administration. Upon
this subject the public mind is too well informed to
be in doubt.-There is no room for hesitation, for
however exalted an opinion the people of this state
may have for the talents and services Mr. Clinton,
they cannot. i'll question affecting the prospective
welfare of the nation, sacrifice their own judgments
in blind reliance on his reference-honestly
formed, perhaps, but evidently founded in er-
r0r.


We make this remark upon the supposition that it
is true that Mr.. Clinton has manifested to some Of
his friends his preference for Gen. Jackson. True
false, thanks to the intelligence of the people, we
are not likely to witness the degradation of the
State, by vassaage to the southern domination.
No coalition, with Martin Van Buren, at its head,
and Noah and Coleman for its supporters, though it
should be sanctioned by the name of Mr.. Clinton,
can preva-more especially when formed for the
corrupt purposes of the union.

October Ia, 1927.


s am happy to see recoil Of public opinion in
favor of the Administration. For some time after
the last Presidential election, many honest well
meaning men were carried TO the side Of the yMilia-
gu Chefiain, by the popular cry of bargain, sale,
bribery, corruption, intrigue" &c. &c. and confess
that myself labored for short time under the same
deIuson and, indeed, strange it was to me, when,
on mature reflection, | took deliberate view of
past events.


The recent publication of the letters on that
subject, and particularly Mr.. Buchanan's, of Penn
sylvana, has operated on the public mind in my
neighborhood, the sun does when he rises to dis
perse the shades of night.


In the recent development alluded to, Clay
has gained triumph over his enemies, (or ra-
thcr they have put themselyes) completely to
shame rejoice in his triumph and hope every
man OF correct principles may come out equally
pure, and pass through the ordeal of public cen
sure with equal credit. have gone to a grea-
ter length on this subject than intended. but could
say much more. 1t is subject that think all i'm
porant at this time to the American People. In
deed, it appears to me we are standing on preci-
pice that ought to be viewed with horror


SOME OF THE GENERALS FRIENDS.
The following remarks by the Richmond Wing,
relative to his neghbor, the Enquirer, and, certain
prominent members of the Opposition, should be
read with great attention in small State of three
counties. True--nolhing is said about Delaware
papers men but the application to them, in part
these remarks, will be easy, and follow almost ir-
resstably.


That this support should be headed and recon-
mended by his former adyersares-by men who
felt pretended TO feel the utmost horror at the
mere possibility of his success-that his success
would endanger liberty and the republic itself, is
phenomenon, which as 1t cannot be explained upon
principles creditable to the human character, we
shall leave altogether uninterrupted. fes--these
men not only opposed Gen. jackson, but they were
the first 10 do it-they not only the first but
they carried their enmity to the most violent ex-
treme--they exposed his MANY military vioences---
Ills contempt of orders his ihractons of the consti-
tulion-ls disregard OF the rights of persons-his
despotlc resort to court martals to ails and to the
Office of the hangman, whenever his wishes were OBJ
structed, or his imperial temper provoked. Reas-
onns upon these exhibitions Of character these gem
temen affirmed that Gen jackson was dangerous in
aRepubc-that he had never been vested with
authority without grossly abusing it--that he had in
every Instance sacrificed the law and the constitu-
ton, personal rights, the liberty of the citizen and
humanity itself to his ungoyernable passions-and
that he was disqualified by nature, by habit and by
education, for any civil office whatever. His pub
lie conduct was scrutinzed with rigorous severity,
and the Enquirer groaned under the load of denun-
clatlon and appeals to the people to their lib
critics from the grasp ofthe Military Despot. Could
possibly be imagined, that any state of things
would thereafter enlist the support of these gen
4 leEaen for Gen. Jackson Could if be believed that
men of responsibility and sense, would in so short
atime give the lie to their former declarations, or
subject themselves to the suspicion of present in
sincerity, when they profess their faith in General
Jackson's capacity 10 rule this country


An opposition thus vicious in its origin could be
supported only by means equally yicious-and hence
that rapid succession OF fabricated charges directed
against the honor and purity of the Administration
the employment of such venal Instruments as dis
grace the American Press--the innumerable false
moods which are coined and thrown into circulation
with rapldity which has kept the people in con-
slant state of excitement, and left them no time to


investigate the truth Of one, before they called
"Ponto examine another Eighteen months ago, we
pronounced this opposition. farther than Virginia
and North Carolina were engaged in it, (and drew
upon ourselves by doing so, denunciation in the Sc
nate of the U. States, factious and unprincipled
tirglnla and N. Carolina alone, could upon princi-
P'e' oppose this administration, for they alone had
"aged consistent war against that latitudinous con-
Suchon which, practlsed under all administrations,
pu' more expressly recognized by Mr.. Monroe's,
,aa been, or it was conjectured, would be adopted
y 4 t mat OF MT. Adams. Beyond these two States
calhoun, Van Buren, Benton, McDufie, Woodbury.


"A. al was facton--for beyond these two States, and
perhaPs Georgia in part all without exception, en-
s"seo IN the uncompromising hostility to Mr.. Ad-
ss and his administration, had invariably, from the
psgnnng of their political lives, supported and ap


that construction of the Constitution and the
I'easures to which it led, upon the basis Of which


ne new administration proposed to conduct the Gov


'lheht. When these men were observed sudden


ana simultaneously, to renounce their old opin-

er of graduates at several principal colleges, in FIVE
successive years.

From, the New- Pork american, October "a.


BY the Cadmus, arrived at this port last evenings
we have received our files of Paris and Havre pa
pers to the 18th Sept.


The quarter to which we look for intelligence of
prominent interest, Greece, yields much upon which
the friends of the cause of liberty may found their
fluctuations. The intervention of the European pow
ers had assumeda serious aspect, and a combined
feet had formed junction off Milo to overlook and
dictate the desnes of the Greeks.

FROM the Nea0 York Commercial of SATURDAY..


IMPORTANT TO THE PEopLE!-In addition to the
partial development OF part of the jackson ope-
ratlons which we gave yestelday,we now enabled
to make another suggestion, OF momentous mpol
tance to the people. We are advised from Albany
that the Albany Jackson Regency have it in conten-
plation, if they carry the Legislature at the ap-
preaching election, TO REPEAL THE ELECt
TORAL LAW, which the people, in their majesty,
wrung from them two years since, and again U.s.
URP The POWER OF APPOIN ling THE
ELEC TORS OF PRESIDENT THEMSELVES. +.
1t is the unquestonabe determination of these men,
that jackson shall be President, though his trium-
pha car be wheeled over the PROSTATE liberties OF
the People!


From, tie Nesv York National .adyocate Of, Saturday


TIE ELECTORAL Law IN DANoER.-it is not to
be doubted that should the combined powerof Clinton
and Van Buren, send to the next legislature Of this
state majority of persons subservient to their views
they would instantly make sacrifice of the elcctor
al law, and take the choice OF President electors
into their own hands. After great struggle the
people Of this state have obtained the just privilege
of themselves appointing the persons who shall elect
the President and Vice President. Let them now
beware how they hazard this important and popular
right by sending to the Legislature those who will de-
prlve them OF 1t. We raise voice of warning; we
bid them beware in 1927 of those men who in 1928
spurned, and contumaciously spurned, the loud
voice of the Freemen of this state. The same man
now as then manages the scenery, and he will not
hesitate when ehas power to use it. Again we re-
peat, preserve your electoral Iaw-and do it at the
polls in the men you send to Albany as your repre-
sentatives.


From the United States Gazette
| Will somebody mend the pocket Of Major Noah's
aam.entionables2 When Delaware promised to vote
for Jackson, the Major said that Delaware had heart
enough for the whole United States. When Della
ware did vote for the administration, the Major said
he ''could put the whole concern in his breeches
pocket"-doubtless the worthy major overlooked
| Mr.. Duponts establishment.


From the Neu- York Commercial .4dvertiser.


General Jackson and General Washington.- -
The friends of the military candidate for the Presi-
dency, have hitherto had reply which they have
deemed convincing, to the apprehension expressed
by sober citizens of the danger Of elevating mere
soldier and Court Martial Judgeto such high and
responsible station that of Head Of our republic.
This knock down argument has been, that General
Washington was soldier too and that General Jack
son would tread in the footsteps Of so illusrious
predecessor The comparison Of the two names
was modest enough on their part to be sure; But

From the 7soy. N. r SentineLl
The following article from the Buffalo Journal o
the 9th inst. viii be read with attention. The Jour
nal has ever been decided supporter OF Mr.. Gin
ton, in state politics, aud the maniness and lndepen
dence of its sentiments as expressed below, arr
therefore the more striking and honourable.


lNr. Giaaton-It has been asserted in several o
the papers. that Mr. Clinton had finally formed ar
alliance offensive 4 defensive, with Mr. Van Buren,
and that of the articles Of the treaty was. tina
Clinton should support Gen. Jackson TOR the Presl
Gency, and himself be the candidate for Vice Pres
ident. The bodness s. air Of certainty with whicl
the assertion was made at first impressed us with
partial belief Of its truth but, after much observa
ton, the unwelcome nature of the news; or th
dulness of our perception, has prevented our com


ing fully to the understanding that such is the fact
in its full sense The American first prOclaims thu
news-the Argus does not deny it; and the Rich
mond Enquirer says he knew it six weeks ago Or
the back of this the Evening Post says: '.We arr
indeed aware that the scurril0us columns of an Ad
ans paper proclaimed in broad terms the slander
that coalition had been entered into between Mr..
Clinton and Mr.. Van Buren,. by which the latter
had agreed to support the former for the office o
Vice President, but the falsehood unfortunate
one, and not beieved.''


So that look where we will (Mr. Clinton not vet
having committed himselfby any public act) we are
at loss how to determine the point. One thing
is certan-let Mr.. Clinton 60 where he may, his
former friends will be found the firm and efficient
supporters of the present Administration. Upon
this subject the public mind is too well informed to
be in doubt.-There is no room for hesitation, for
however exalted an opinion the people of this state
may have for the talents and services Mr. Clinton,
they cannot. i'll question affecting the prospective
welfare of the nation, sacrifice their own judgments
in blind reliance on his reference-honestly
formed, perhaps, but evidently founded in er-
r0r.


We make this remark upon the supposition that it
is true that Mr.. Clinton has manifested to some Of
his friends his preference for Gen. Jackson. True
false, thanks to the intelligence of the people, we
are not likely to witness the degradation of the
State, by vassaage to the southern domination.
No coalition, with Martin Van Buren, at its head,
and Noah and Coleman for its supporters, though it
should be sanctioned by the name of Mr.. Clinton,
can preva-more especially when formed for the
corrupt purposes of the union.

October Ia, 1927.


s am happy to see recoil Of public opinion in
favor of the Administration. For some time after
the last Presidential election, many honest well
meaning men were carried TO the side Of the yMilia-
gu Chefiain, by the popular cry of bargain, sale,
bribery, corruption, intrigue" &c. &c. and confess
that myself labored for short time under the same
deIuson and, indeed, strange it was to me, when,
on mature reflection, | took deliberate view of
past events.


The recent publication of the letters on that
subject, and particularly Mr.. Buchanan's, of Penn
sylvana, has operated on the public mind in my
neighborhood, the sun does when he rises to dis
perse the shades of night.


In the recent development alluded to, Clay
has gained triumph over his enemies, (or ra-
thcr they have put themselyes) completely to
shame rejoice in his triumph and hope every
man OF correct principles may come out equally
pure, and pass through the ordeal of public cen
sure with equal credit. have gone to a grea-
ter length on this subject than intended. but could
say much more. 1t is subject that think all i'm
porant at this time to the American People. In
deed, it appears to me we are standing on preci-
pice that ought to be viewed with horror


SOME OF THE GENERALS FRIENDS.
The following remarks by the Richmond Wing,
relative to his neghbor, the Enquirer, and, certain
prominent members of the Opposition, should be
read with great attention in small State of three
counties. True--nolhing is said about Delaware
papers men but the application to them, in part
these remarks, will be easy, and follow almost ir-
resstably.


That this support should be headed and recon-
mended by his former adyersares-by men who
felt pretended TO feel the utmost horror at the
mere possibility of his success-that his success
would endanger liberty and the republic itself, is
phenomenon, which as 1t cannot be explained upon
principles creditable to the human character, we
shall leave altogether uninterrupted. fes--these
men not only opposed Gen. jackson, but they were
the first 10 do it-they not only the first but
they carried their enmity to the most violent ex-
treme--they exposed his MANY military vioences---
Ills contempt of orders his ihractons of the consti-
tulion-ls disregard OF the rights of persons-his
despotlc resort to court martals to ails and to the
Office of the hangman, whenever his wishes were OBJ
structed, or his imperial temper provoked. Reas-
onns upon these exhibitions Of character these gem
temen affirmed that Gen jackson was dangerous in
aRepubc-that he had never been vested with
authority without grossly abusing it--that he had in
every Instance sacrificed the law and the constitu-
ton, personal rights, the liberty of the citizen and
humanity itself to his ungoyernable passions-and
that he was disqualified by nature, by habit and by
education, for any civil office whatever. His pub
lie conduct was scrutinzed with rigorous severity,
and the Enquirer groaned under the load of denun-
clatlon and appeals to the people to their lib
critics from the grasp ofthe Military Despot. Could
possibly be imagined, that any state of things
would thereafter enlist the support of these gen
4 leEaen for Gen. Jackson Could if be believed that
men of responsibility and sense, would in so short
atime give the lie to their former declarations, or
subject themselves to the suspicion of present in
sincerity, when they profess their faith in General
Jackson's capacity 10 rule this country


An opposition thus vicious in its origin could be
supported only by means equally yicious-and hence
that rapid succession OF fabricated charges directed
against the honor and purity of the Administration
the employment of such venal Instruments as dis
grace the American Press--the innumerable false
moods which are coined and thrown into circulation
with rapldity which has kept the people in con-
slant state of excitement, and left them no time to


investigate the truth Of one, before they called
"Ponto examine another Eighteen months ago, we
pronounced this opposition. farther than Virginia
and North Carolina were engaged in it, (and drew
upon ourselves by doing so, denunciation in the Sc
nate of the U. States, factious and unprincipled
tirglnla and N. Carolina alone, could upon princi-
P'e' oppose this administration, for they alone had
"aged consistent war against that latitudinous con-

pu' more expressly recognized by Mr.. Monroe's,

y 4 t mat OF MT. Adams. Beyond these two States
calhoun, Van Buren, Benton, McDufie, Woodbury.

ss and his administration, had invariably, from the

that construction of the Constitution and the

ne new administration proposed to conduct the Gov

From, the New- Pork american, October "a.


BY the Cadmus, arrived at this port last evenings
we have received our files of Paris and Havre pa
pers to the 18th Sept.


The quarter to which we look for intelligence of
prominent interest, Greece, yields much upon which
the friends of the cause of liberty may found their
fluctuations. The intervention of the European pow
ers had assumeda serious aspect, and a combined
feet had formed junction off Milo to overlook and
dictate the desnes of the Greeks.

full articles.headline: From the NeaO York Commercial of Safatrduu.
full articles.article:
FROM the Nea0 York Commercial of SATURDAY..


IMPORTANT TO THE PEopLE!-In addition to the
partial development OF part of the jackson ope-
ratlons which we gave yestelday,we now enabled
to make another suggestion, OF momentous mpol
tance to the people. We are advised from Albany
that the Albany Jackson Regency have it in conten-
plation, if they carry the Legislature at the ap-
preaching election, TO REPEAL THE ELECt
TORAL LAW, which the people, in their majesty,
wrung from them two years since, and again U.s.
URP The POWER OF APPOIN ling THE
ELEC TORS OF PRESIDENT THEMSELVES. +.
1t is the unquestonabe determination of these men,
that jackson shall be President, though his trium-
pha car be wheeled over the PROSTATE liberties OF
the People!


From, tie Nesv York National .adyocate Of, Saturday


TIE ELECTORAL Law IN DANoER.-it is not to
be doubted that should the combined powerof Clinton
and Van Buren, send to the next legislature Of this
state majority of persons subservient to their views
they would instantly make sacrifice of the elcctor
al law, and take the choice OF President electors
into their own hands. After great struggle the
people Of this state have obtained the just privilege
of themselves appointing the persons who shall elect
the President and Vice President. Let them now
beware how they hazard this important and popular
right by sending to the Legislature those who will de-
prlve them OF 1t. We raise voice of warning; we
bid them beware in 1927 of those men who in 1928
spurned, and contumaciously spurned, the loud
voice of the Freemen of this state. The same man
now as then manages the scenery, and he will not
hesitate when ehas power to use it. Again we re-
peat, preserve your electoral Iaw-and do it at the
polls in the men you send to Albany as your repre-
sentatives.

From the Neu- York Commercial .4dvertiser.


General Jackson and General Washington.- -
The friends of the military candidate for the Presi-
dency, have hitherto had reply which they have
deemed convincing, to the apprehension expressed
by sober citizens of the danger Of elevating mere
soldier and Court Martial Judgeto such high and
responsible station that of Head Of our republic.
This knock down argument has been, that General
Washington was soldier too and that General Jack
son would tread in the footsteps Of so illusrious
predecessor The comparison Of the two names
was modest enough on their part to be sure; But
